From : R. J. Stone & Associates
PHONE No. : 617 447 7720
Jan. 19 1995 11:36AM P13 :selected:
BURADARIRE JE 40261
Smoking ban idea criticized at hearing
Brewster straw poll kicks off debate By JOHN LEANING STAFF WRITER
d
BREWSTER - Based on a struw vote taken at laut'night's board of health hearing on a proposed townwide smoking ban in- public places, the regulation would have lost by nearly a 2-to-1 margin.
But the informal survey of those in the audience who raised their hands - 17 against, nine for - was only Â« preliminary round in a debate that will heat up as & 17- town, no-smoking campaign en- compassing Cape Cod and Nan- tucket takes hold.
Those opposed to the regula- tions - drafted by the Cape Cod Regional Tobacco Control Pro- gram -- included smokers, former smokers, owners of businesses selling tobacco or of bars or restau- rante where at least sorde arena are upen to smokers,
Supportare of the ban said they were speaking In defense of their own right, and the rights of chil- dren, lo breathe air free from soc- ond-hand amoke.
Opponents warned of looming government intervention, the loss of personal freedoms, the arrival of "Big Brother" and the loss of busi- ness from smoking customers or tourists who elect to take their business, and their smoking hab- Its, elsewhere,
Bobby Dyrne, owner of three rea-
The informal survey was only a preliminary round In a debate that will heat up.
taurante on the Cape - although none are in Drewater - sold no would see his revenue "annihilat- ed" if & smoking ban were im- poscd. Local pub and restaurant owners raised similar concerne, wondering if private clubs would. be able to circumvent the ragula- tions and allow smoking by selling "private" membership cards.
Likening second-hand smoke to water pollution, Rebecca Koeppen said, "To avold second-hand smoke, I'd like very much to know I can go into a restaurant and not smell cigarette smoke."
Under the smoke-free campaign, funded by an a tax increase on ci- gerettos approved by the state's voters in 1992, boards of health in the 17 towns are to act on identical regulations barring smoking in all public places. Similar efforts are under way in other parts of the state.
The Brewster health board used last night's meeting to get public input, and will schedule another hearing once formal regulations are available and have beon re- viewed by town counsel.
